titles.title: Bureau of Engraving and Printing Security Printing Amendments Act of 2000

To authorize the Secretary of the Treasury to produce currency, postage stamps, and other security documents at the request of foreign governments, and security documents at the request of the individual States or any political subdivision thereof, on a reimbursable basis, and for other purposes.

action.text: Referred to the House Committee on Banking and Financial Services.
Referred to the Subcommittee on Domestic and International Monetary Policy.

committee.name: House Committee on Banking and Financial Services

action.text: Subcommittee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.

committee.name: House Committee on Banking and Financial Services

action.text: Forwarded by Subcommittee to Full Committee by Voice Vote.

committee.name: House Committee on Banking and Financial Services

action.text: Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.

committee.name: House Committee on Banking and Financial Services

calendar.text: Ordered to be Reported by Voice Vote.

committee.name: House Committee on Banking and Financial Services

action.text: Reported by the Committee on Banking and Financial Services. H. Rept. 106-849.

calendar.text: Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 504.

action.text: Mr. Bachus moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 4096.

vote.text: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.

action.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Received in the Senate and Read twice and referred to the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs.

committee.name: Senate Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs

bill.summary: 3/28/2000--Introduced. Bureau of Engraving and Printing Security Printing Amendments Act of 2000 - Amends Federal law relating to engraving and printing currency and security documents to authorize the Secretary of the Treasury to produce: (1) currency, postage stamps, and other security documents for foreign governments (subject to a determination by the Secretary of State that such production is consistent with U.S. foreign policy), and (2) security documents for States and their political subdivisions.Instructs the Secretary to impose charges for such services.
